body:
@Osmose @mythmon 
1.  `//` is used for floor division, so '#' it is.
2.  Test cases updated to work with multiline, nested and '#' in values.
3.  Same basic design:  lexer just 'throws comments away' so parser never has to deal with them.  It is possible to put these nodes on the AST, but a lot more work.  

So, what do other people do?
- dropping comments at the Lexer is common.
- python ran into issues once they started type-hinting.  http://www.psf.upfronthosting.co.za/issue24119
- esprima drops them at the Lexer:  http://esprima.org/demo/parse.html#

body_html:
@Osmose @mythmon

  1. // is used for floor division, so '#' it is.
  2. Test cases updated to work with multiline, nested and '#' in values.
  3. Same basic design: lexer just 'throws comments away' so parser never has to deal with them. It is possible to put these nodes on the AST, but a lot more work.

So, what do other people do?

  • dropping comments at the Lexer is common.
  • python ran into issues once they started type-hinting. http://www.psf.upfronthosting.co.za/issue24119
  • esprima drops them at the Lexer: http://esprima.org/demo/parse.html#
